1610524611_1HesgY39DUQrf3M1WCn6q66f69VRR.body:
> [wehatefreespeech](#comment_2_17VhNL7f9QRGPz9fV6wjCfY1qzFBnVybZa): I always get the most crude stuff on here. Is there a way to avoid that. I do want some form of moderation and not kiddie porn and nazis.

When you hover your mouse over the first line of a comment three dots appear on the right side. Click on those and you will be able to mute the user. Watch the upper right corner for a message, click on the "mute" button in that message to block all further content from this user.

1610660211_1CrFEcv59gAFWe7w5wbKxCYJg3sDg.body:
You can't combine these technologies, they are fundamentally different and ZeroNet Zites do not work like traditional web applications. For instance, there is no database server to store your data in, you can use Coffeescript, but the database will be available to every peer on ZeroNet. You have to keep in mind that all of the code of a Zite is exposed to its peers.

You can run a "traditional" web application and have a Zite that just renders pre-generated HTML supplied by the traditional web application via an API for instance, that would be possible and could somehow be combined with Inrupt, but I don't see any concrete use case.

What would be a use case that you're thinking of?

1610661458_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body: I don't understand the question or the use case. You can use Filepacks with React, Angular or Node for non-exclusives sites, no? Can you explain your use case (or issue) more thoroughly?

I guess that most people just don't know about them or that they do not need them. Flatpacks add another layer of complexity to your site, so if there is no direct benefit to using them for your site, it would just be additional work.
That's pretty much it, yeah. Useful for large-ish TOR sites with a lot of assets, but for 99.9999% of the sites it will not be worth the (even if admittedly small) effort.
Great point and good thinking! Will certainly look into using them for my zites, too.

Depending on what level you want to reach (CEFR) and which disciplines (ie. good at reading, bad at speaking) there are different methodologies.

A fool-proof way of preparing yourself for a professional use of Russian is to move to a country where Russian is the national language and to spend some time there. This is almost always needed if you want to properly localize or internationalize into/from that language.

1610882790_19s3iztHV7i3fBN9wyiMhiXECoZvy.body:
Are you on Windoze? If yes, go to settings and look for the toggle "launch browser" and toggle it to off.

Then just follow the instructions as per Zeronet FAQ:

***
Edit: removed because this does not work anymore with newer versions of TOR Browser.
***
Zeronet FAQ:
http://127.0.0.1:43110/1DocsYf2tZVVMEMJFHiDsppmFicZCWkVv1/faq/
***

** Does not work with newer versions of the TOR Browser for the following reasons:**

>You should really avoid making exceptions to the proxy rules for Tor Browser. If you let your browser connect to local services, that opens the door for remote websites, which you access over Tor, to give you instructions (e.g. via javascript, but not only via javascript) to make local connections and then send that info back to the website.
>
>In the most benign case, you're setting yourself up with a tracking marker ("there's that weird person who allowed connections to 192.168.1.1 again"). In worse cases, you're opening yourself up to permissions surprises and attacks that start with the word "cross-site" or "cross-protocol".
>
>For an early example of a similar bug that bit Tor users, see https://lists.torproject.org/pipermail/tor-announce/2007-September/000078.html
>
>All of that said, if you still want to shoot your feet off: in about:config, there's a network.proxy.no_proxies_on option that you can set.

>For even more details, new in ESR68, there is now a network.proxy.allow_hijacking_localhost option, which we needed to fix for Tor Browser: https://bugs.torproject.org/31065

In general TOR and Zeronet do not work well together, because Zeronet requires Javascript, which can expose client details to sites. So keep that in mind when using Zeronet over TOR.

Edit ZeroNet.sh and make sure it looks like this:

>\#!/bin/bash
>SCRIPT_DIR=$( cd ${0%/*} && pwd -P )
>cd "$SCRIPT_DIR"
>SCRIPT="core/zeronet.py"
>runtime/bin/python3 "$SCRIPT_DIR/$SCRIPT" --dist_type bundle_linux64 "$@"

I've basically just removed the IF statement that checks if X11 or Darwin is running.
Or create your own run-script if you want it to be cleaner ;-)

You will still have to shoot your feet off by editing "proxy.no_proxies_on" setting in TOR browser.

From the FAQ:

*Can I use the same username on multiple machines?*
Yes, simply copy the data/users.json file to your new machine.
